fullText:
As backers' auditions go, "Gutenberg! The Musical!" — a wildly delusional conceit so full of itself that it boasts two exclamation points — doesn't stand a chance of making it to Broadway. That is, unless it can convince an audience of potential producers that it is witnessing the greatest creation since, well, the printing press.

It greatly helps that this starry-eyed writer-composer duo from Nutley, New Jersey who are desperately selling their show — emphasis on desperately — are played by Josh Gad and Andrew Rannells, reunited 12 years after their terrific pairing in "The Book of Mormon." It almost makes it all worthwhile — almost.
dtliExcerpt: Josh Gad and Andrew Rannells are so committed to their roles as bumbling aspiring musical theater writers that they make even the worst songs seem intentionally terrible.
showScoreExcerpt: Josh Gad and Andrew Rannells are so committed to their roles as bumbling aspiring musical theater writers that they make even the worst songs seem intentionally terrible.

keyPhrases.quote: doesn't stand a chance of making it to Broadway
It almost makes it all worthwhile — almost

llmScore.reasoning: The critic pans the show concept as delusional and destined to fail, but praises Gad and Rannells' performances, with the crucial qualifier that their star power 'almost' makes it worthwhile.
